That PmrB is likely to sense changes in pH directly is supported by three findings: ( i) the mild acid pH - dependent activation of the PmrA - regulated gene pbgP was dramatically reduced in a strain lacking pmrB ( Fig. 3), ( ii) the periplasmic domain of PmrB was necessary for activation of pbgP under mild acid conditions ( Fig. 5), and ( iii) single amino acid substitutions in conserved histidine and glutamic acid residues located in the periplasmic domain of PmrB abolished its ability to stimulate pbgP transcription at pH 5. 8 ( Fig. 6).
